body.p: Everyone has a body, and, by adulthood, a general understanding of how it works. But truly appreciating the intricate functions of the human body—and the problems that occur when something goes wrong—requires an organized approach. This course will help you understand the functions of the human body. We will discuss the details of many complex functional systems, but will also look at how all of these systems work in harmony to keep you healthy.

As we move through this course, we will keep four main themes in mind. The first of these themes is the connection between structure and function. You know from the course title that we will be studying both anatomy, which focuses on the body’s structures, and physiology, which focuses on the body’s functions. In fact, it is virtually impossible to study one without the other, because function relies so completely upon structure. For example, the structure of our skeletal system provides the support necessary for the function of walking upright. The shape of the vocal cords is essential to the production of sound waves. The coordinated movements of the bones in the knee joints dictate the direction in which our legs bend. And the list goes on.

Our second theme will be homeostasis, or the body’s natural tendency to maintain a stable environment. We will examine the manner in which all of the body’s functions are driven by homeostasis. Homeostasis occurs at the cellular level through processes such as osmosis, which maintains the balance of nutrients within cells. Homeostatic processes also affect an entire organism at once. Your body automatically shivers to generate heat and maintain temperature balance. When you feel hungry, it is because your body needs to be brought back into nutritional balance.

The third theme of our course will include a study of the structural levels of the body. The most basic is the chemical level, in which atoms and molecules interact to process nutrients and produce substances needed for life. These particles combine in specialized structures, cells, which are the smallest unit of life. Cells of a similar type combine to form tissues, and tissues are combined into organs. Organs do not work independently; they are organized into organ systems that complete more complex tasks. The digestive system, for example, includes the mouth, stomach, intestines, and many other organs—all of which are integral to proper functioning of the system as a whole. The organ systems work together to support life in the entire organism, in our case a human being.

Finally, in each section of the course we will discuss the integration of all the body’s systems. In order to carry out its functions, every organ system relies on the healthy functioning of other systems. When these systems all work together, the organism thrives.
